title: MARKET SNAPSHOT: Stock-index Futures Edge Higher As Trade Deal Hopes Rise
text:
By William Watts and Chris Matthews, MarketWatch

Beyond Meat jumps premarket after McDonald's announces trial run for plant-based burger

U.S. stock-index futures pointed to a slightly higher start for Wall Street on Thursday after investors shook off the launch of an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump and focused on positive noises around U.S.-China trade negotiations.

What are major indexes doing?

Futures on the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 44 points, or 0.2%, to 27,000, while S&P 500 futures gained 3.95 points, or 0.1%, to 2,990. Nasdaq-100 futures were up 3.75 points at 7,824, a gain of 0.1%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 162.94 points Wednesday to end at 26,970.71, up 0.6%, while the S&P 500 rose 18.27 points, or 0.6%, to 2,984.87. The Nasdaq Composite ended at 8,077.38 with a gain of 83.76 points, or 1.1%.

What's driving the market?

Stocks were boosted Wednesday after Trump told reporters an end to the U.S.-China trade war could happen "sooner than you think" and repeated that China wants "to make a deal very badly." The Chinese Commerce Ministry confirmed China has made purchases of U.S. soybeans and pork (link) ahead of trade talks due in October.

Also late Wednesday President Trump signed a new trade deal (link)with Japan covering investment, agricultural products and digital trade, but automobile tariffs were excluded.

Economic developments, not the possible impeachment of President Trump, will likely be more important for stocks, analysts said, though there is debate (link)about how the impeachment process may impact trade negotiations (link). The immediate impact may be felt on U.S. spending decisions and the chances for passage of the USMCA deal (link)to replace Nafta. The White House and Congress must agree on a new spending deal Nov. 21 to prevent another government shutdown.

Investors on Wednesday largely brushed off the decision by House Democrats to begin a formal impeachment inquiry into Trump amid a controversy over his interaction with Ukraine's president. On Thursday, Joseph Maguire, acting director of national intelligence, is scheduled to testify before the House Intelligence Committee about the whistleblower complaint from a member of the intelligence community that raised concerns about Trump's relationship with Ukraine.

The whistleblower complaint was released by the House panel Thursday morning.

"Frustration is mounting for the bears as the market refuses to break below support despite what they see as a growing list of reasons for a selloff," said Jeff deGraaf, founder of Renaissance Macro Research, in a note.

"To us, the market's ability to absorb the barrage of punches and maintain its ground is a sign of resiliency and strength. We want to be buyers of resilient markets as eventually the punches will exhaust and the market will thrive on relief," he said.

On the economic data front, new applications for jobless benefits rose (link) by 3,000 to 213,000 during the week ended Sept. 21, above economist expectations of 211,000 according to a MarketWatch poll.

The final estimate for second-quarter GDP growth came in unchanged (link) at 2% annualized, the Commerce Department said Thursday. Meanwhile, the U.S. trade deficit widened slightly (link) in August to $72.8 billion but smaller than the $74 billion consensus, according to a MarketWatch poll.

An index on pending home sales for August is due at 10 a.m.

A spate of Federal Reserve officials will give remarks Thursday, starting with Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan, a nonvoting member of the central bank's interest-setting committee, will give opening remarks at a conference on trade and immigration at 9.30 a.m. Eastern Time, followed by St. Louis Fed President James Bullard, a voter, who will speak at a conference on minorities in banking at 10 a.m.

There Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Richard Clarida is due to speak at 11:45 a.m., and San Francisco Fed President Mary Daly, a non-voter, will speak at noon. Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari, also a non-voter, will speak at a town hall in Billings, Montana, at 2 p.m.

Which stocks are in focus?

General Motors Co. (GM) and the United Autoworkers Union are reported (link) to be close to an agreement to end a strike. Shares rose 1.4% in premarket trade.

Facebook Inc. (FB) shares fell 1.1% in premarket action, after a report (link) the company is the subject of a U.S. Justice Department antitrust investigation, even as a Federal Trade Commission enquiry is already under way.

Shares of Beyond Meat Inc.(BYND) jumped nearly 13% in premarket activity after McDonald's Corp. (MCD) said it would trial a plant-based burger made by the company at 28 restaurants in Canada.

Shares of Rite Aid Corp. (RAD) rallied 9.8% before the start of trade, after the drugstore chain reported an adjusted fiscal second-quarter profit (link) that beat expectations, though revenue fell a bit short.

Peloton Interactive Inc., a web-connected exercise-equipment company, on Wednesday priced shares in its initial public offering at $29 a share (link), the top of the targeted range. Shares are expected to begin trading Thursday morning on the Nasdaq Global Select Market.

See:Peloton IPO: 5 things to know about the interactive exercise company (link)

In deal news, NGL Energy Partners L.P.(NGL) announced Thursday an agreement (link) to buy Hillstone Environmental Partners LLC for about $600 million from Golden Gate Capital.

How are other markets performing?

U.S. Treasury yields fell on Thursday (link)as geopolitical jitters from Washington, Iran and the U.K. boosted demand for haven assets like U.S. government paper. The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury note fell about one basis point to 1.715%.

In commodities markets, oil futures drifted lower Thursday (link), continuing to give back gains made in the wake of Sept. 14 attacks on Saudi production facilities as news reports cite progress in restoring output and U.S. inventories.rise. West Texas Intermediate crude oil prices for November delivery edged lower to about $56 a barrel, while the price of gold edged higher to roughly $1,516 an ounce. The U.S. dollar , meanwhile, traded mostly flat against a basket of its peers.

Asian stocks traded mixed overnight, with the China CSI 300 index falling 0.8%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index added 0.4% and Japan's Nikkei 225 rose 0.1%.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 26, 2019 08:59 ET (12:59 GMT)
